ci_support_linux_64_r_base4.4.yaml:
cdt_name:
- conda
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
cran_mirror:
- https://cran.r-project.org
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
pin_run_as_build:
  r-base:
    min_pin: x.x
    max_pin: x.x
r_base:
- '4.4'
target_platform:
- linux-64

about.description: In some cases you will have data in a histogram format, where you have a vector of all possible observations, and a vector of how many times each observation appeared.  You could expand this into a single 1D vector, but this may not be advisable if the counts are extremely large. 'HistDat' allows for the calculation of summary statistics without the need for expanding your data.

In some cases you will have data in a histogram format, where you have a vector of all possible observations, and a vector of how many times each observation appeared.  You could expand this into a single 1D vector, but this may not be advisable if the counts are extremely large. 'HistDat' allows for the calculation of summary statistics without the need for expanding your data.

name: r-histdat
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = '0.2.0' %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-histdat
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/HistDat_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/HistDat/HistDat_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 20b89f1845645011b2eb39b21ac6d5bec5bb3499cba59c69c2884c8c94d4fd1b

build:
  number: 4
  noarch: generic
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
    - cross-r-base {{ r_base }}    # [build_platform != target_platform]
  host:
    - r-base
  run:
    - r-base

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('HistDat')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('HistDat')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=HistDat
  license: GPL-3.0-or-later
  summary: Summary Statistics for Histogram/Count Data
  description: In some cases you will have data in a histogram format, where you
    have a vector of all possible observations, and a vector of how
    many times each observation appeared.  You could expand this into
    a single 1D vector, but this may not be advisable if the counts
    are extremely large. 'HistDat' allows for the calculation of
    summary statistics without the need for expanding your data.
  license_family: GPL3
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/GPL-3'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r
    - epruesse
